title: Few big foreign firms bid in Mexico's first oil auction
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Jul 15, 2015, 19:01 BST - UK Markets closed Few big foreign firms bid in Mexico's first oil auction By Laurent Thomet | AFP â€“ 21 minutes ago View Photo 

Only nine of 25 global energy firms and consortiums that entered Mexico's historic oil auction made offers on Wednesday, as some industry giants shunned the sale. 
The government was auctioning off 14 oil fields in shallow water of the Gulf of Mexico worth a total of $17 billion, the first sale in an energy reform that ends the state's 77-year monopoly on drilling. 
But US giants ExxonMobil and Chevron, Anglo-Australian firm BHP Billiton (NYSE: BBL - news ) , France's Total (Swiss: FP.SW - news ) and Russia's Lukoil did not make any bids despite having qualified for the auction. 
Norway's Statoil (Xetra: 675213 - news ) , Italy's ENI (NYSE: E - news ) and India's ONGC Videsh Ltd were among the few that decided to participate. 
Only one of the first five blocks that were auctioned off had a winner, a consortium led by one of Mexico's newest independent energy firms, Sierra Oil & Gas, which offered the state nearly 56 percent of proceeds for a field containing light crude. 
A team comprising US firm Murphy Worldwide and Malaysia's Petronas made an offer of 35 percent for the fourth block, but it was under the government's demand of 40 percent. 
Nobody made offers for the three other fields. 
The auction was the climax of President Enrique Pena Nieto's top economic reform, which was enacted last year after a heated debate in Congress, with leftist parties warning against giving up a symbol of national sovereignty. 
The government had played down expectations of a big sale, predicting that between a third and half of the 14 blocks would be awarded. More complex blocks such as deep-water oil fields will be auctioned off at a later date. 
Energy Minister Pedro Joaquin Coldwell said earlier this week that the estimate was in line with international experience. 
"We won't squander the nation's oil resources," he said. 
Daniel Sanchez, a Mexico-based energy expert at international law firm White & Case, told AFP that it was not surprising that big oil firms stayed out, as they will prefer to wait for the more lucrative deep-water oil auction a few months from now. 
"It was expected that these big companies would show very little attention," Sanchez said. "They came in (to the first round) to get to know the process." 
"It doesn't mean that there's not interest. It means that they are well focused somewhere else." 
A bad auction would be another blow to Pena Nieto's administration following the embarrassing fallout of the weekend jailbreak of the country's most powerful drug lord, Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman, his second escape in 14 years. 
- First (Other OTC: FSTC - news ) foothold in Mexico - 
The sharp drop in global oil prices in the past year have affected the plans of energy companies, according to analysts. 
Ahead of the auction, Raymundo Tenorio Aguilar, an energy expert at the Monterrey Institute of Technology, said Tuesday's nuclear deal between Iran and world powers could be a factor. 
The accord will eventually lift sanctions on Iran's oil exports, adding 1.5 million barrels of crude per day in the market, causing prices to fall further, Tenorio said. 
"This weakens Mexico's ability to negotiate," he told AFP. "If only half of the bids are awarded, it would be a success given the current environment." 
- Revive production - 
The legislation breaks the monopoly on drilling held by state-run firm Pemex since the industry's 1938 nationalization. 
While Pemex qualified for the auction, it was sitting out this time. 
Pena Nieto hopes the reform will reverse years of declining production -- from 3.5 million barrels per day in 2004 to 2.3 million now -- and give a boost to the economy. 
Oil auctions are a new thing for Mexico and officials wanted to make them the most transparent in the world. The event was shown on a live Internet broadcast. 
Analysts say the government made an effort to create a transparent system to ease any concerns over the country's poor track record when it comes to corruption.
